table: Evaluation and Treatment of Infants Up to 1 Month of Age with Possible, Probable, or Confirmed Congenital Syphilis

categories.name: Proven or Highly Probable Congenital Syphilis

treatment.preferred: Aqueous crystalline penicillin G, 50,000 U/kg IV, every 12 hours (for infants 1 week or younger), then every 8 hours for infants older than 1 week, for a total of 10 days of therapy

treatment.alternative: Penicillin G procaine, 50,000 U/kg IM, as a single daily dose for 10 days

categories.name: Possible Congenital Syphilis
findings: Normal infant examination
A serum quantitative nontreponemal serologic titer less than fourfold the birthing parent’s titer at delivery (e.g., maternal titer = 1:8, neonatal titer ≤16)
ONE OF THE FOLLOWING:
Birthing parent was not treated, was inadequately treated, or had no documentation of receiving treatment
Birthing parent was treated with a regimen other than the recommended guideline (i.e., a non-penicillin G regimen)
Birthing parent received the recommended regimen but treatment was initiated <30 days before delivery
recommended_evaluation: CSF analysis (CSF VDRL, cell count, and protein)
CBC with differential and platelet count

treatment.preferred: Aqueous crystalline penicillin G, 50,000 U/kg IV, every 12 hours (1 week or younger), then every 8 hours for infants older than 1 week, for a total of 10 days of therapy

treatment.alternative_1: Penicillin G procaine, 50,000 U/kg IM, as a single daily dose for 10 days

treatment.alternative_2: Penicillin G benzathine, 50,000 U/kg IM, single dose (recommended by some experts, but only if all evaluation components are normal and follow-up is certain)

categories.name: Congenital Syphilis Less Likely
findings: Normal infant examination
A serum quantitative nontreponemal serologic titer less than fourfold the birthing parent’s titer at delivery (e.g., maternal titer = 1:8, neonatal titer ≤16)
Birthing parent was treated during pregnancy with an appropriate regimen, treatment was initiated ≥30 days before delivery, and there is no evidence of reinfection or relapse

treatment.preferred: Penicillin G benzathine, 50,000 U/kg IM, single dose

treatment.alternative: Infants whose birthing parent’s nontreponemal titers decreased at least fourfold after appropriate therapy for early syphilis or remained stable at a low titer (e.g., VDRL ≤1:2; RPR ≤1:4) may be followed every 2–3 months without treatment until the nontreponemal test becomes nonreactive.

treatment.follow_up: Nontreponemal antibody titers should decrease by 3 months of age and be nonreactive by 6 months. Infants with increasing or persistent stable titers 6–12 months after treatment should be reevaluated, including a CSF examination, and treated with a 10-day course of parenteral penicillin G.

categories.name: Congenital Syphilis Unlikely
findings: Normal infant examination
A serum quantitative nontreponemal serologic titer less than fourfold the birthing parent’s titer at delivery
Birthing parent was adequately treated before pregnancy
Birthing parent’s nontreponemal serologic titer remained low and stable (i.e., serofast) before and during pregnancy and at delivery (e.g., VDRL ≤1:2 or RPR ≤1:4)

treatment.none_required: None required, but infants with reactive nontreponemal tests should be followed serologically to ensure test results return to negative.

treatment.optional: Penicillin G benzathine, 50,000 U/kg IM, single dose can be considered if follow-up is uncertain and infant has a reactive test (some experts recommend this approach).

treatment.follow_up: Neonates with a negative nontreponemal test result at birth and whose birthing parent was seroreactive at delivery should be retested at 3 months to rule out incubating congenital syphilis.

categories.name: Non-reactive RPR/VDRL and Non-Reactive treponemal test
findings: If epidemiologic risk and clinical probability of syphilis is low, no further evaluation is required
If not low, consider repeat RPR or VDRL in 2-4 weeks to differentiate early primary infection from false positive

categories.name: Reactive RPR/VDRL and Non-Reactive treponemal test
findings: False-positive reaction: no further evaluation
(if pregnant, repeating with another treponemal test may be appropriate)

categories.name: No Result found, please check inputs
findings: Required Inputs: RPR/VDRL test result, Parent Treatement History, Maternal and Infant Titers and Date, Infant Examination
Conditional Inputs: Alternative Treponemal Test of RPR/VDRL is non-reactive
No results found using the algorithm found in the AAP Red Book
